title: CLAUDE.md
text: analysis module follows pattern: - modulename.h.R - Header file defining jamovi interface (Options/Results classes) - modulename.b.R - Body file R6 class implementation - inherit jmvcore base classes

title: CLAUDE.md
text: R6 Class Architecture modules use R6 classes: modulenameClass <- R6::R6Class("modulenameClass", inherit = modulenameBase, ...) Standard methods: initialize(), .init(), .run() Results populated .run() method Options-Results Pattern Utility Functions (R/utils.R) extract_function_name() - Extracts test names formulas extract_kable() - Processes gt/gtsummary tables Diagnostic test statistics: calcStats(), calcLikelihoodRatios(), oddsratio2x2() ROC analysis: calcOptimalCutoff(), calcYouden()
code: # Options define inputs moduleOptions <- jmvcore::Options$new(...)  # Results define outputs (tables, plots, text) moduleResults <- jmvcore::Results$new(...)

title: Biomarker Response Association Analysis - Comprehensive Guide for Precision Medicine
text: Biomarker response association analysis forms cornerstone precision medicine, enabling clinicians researchers understand relationships biological markers treatment outcomes. comprehensive guide demonstrates analyze biomarker-response relationships using ClinicoPath module clinical decision support research validation.

previous_headings: Introduction to Biomarker Response Analysis > What are Biomarker-Response Associations?
title: Biomarker Response Association Analysis - Comprehensive Guide for Precision Medicine
text: Biomarker-response associations quantify biological markers predict, correlate , influence treatment responses. relationships enable: Treatment Selection: Choosing optimal therapies based biomarker profiles Response Prediction: Estimating likelihood treatment success Dose Optimization: Adjusting treatment intensity based biomarker levels Resistance Monitoring: Detecting treatment failure early Clinical Trial Design: Stratifying patients selecting endpoints

previous_headings: Introduction to Biomarker Response Analysis > What are Biomarker-Response Associations?
title: Biomarker Response Association Analysis - Comprehensive Guide for Precision Medicine
text: 📊 Predictive Biomarkers: Predict response specific treatments - HER2 trastuzumab therapy - EGFR mutations tyrosine kinase inhibitors - PD-L1 expression immunotherapy 🎯 Prognostic Biomarkers: Predict disease outcome regardless treatment - Ki-67 tumor proliferation - p53 mutations survival - Tumor grade recurrence risk ⚖️ Pharmacodynamic Biomarkers: Monitor treatment effects - PSA prostate cancer therapy - HbA1c diabetes management - Viral load antiviral therapy 🧬 Companion Diagnostics: Required treatment selection - BRCA mutations PARP inhibitors - MSI status immunotherapy - ALK rearrangements targeted therapy

previous_headings: Getting Started with Biomarker Response Analysis
title: Biomarker Response Association Analysis - Comprehensive Guide for Precision Medicine
text: biomarker response analysis workflow jamovi follows steps: Variable Selection: Choose biomarker response variables Response Type Definition: Specify binary, categorical, continuous responses Threshold Analysis: Determine optimal biomarker cutoffs Statistical Testing: Assess biomarker-response associations Visualization: Generate publication-ready plots Clinical Interpretation: Translate results actionable insights

title: Biomarker Response Association Analysis - Comprehensive Guide for Precision Medicine
text: Analyzing whether biomarker predicts treatment response (responder vs. non-responder). Key Biomarker Characteristics Binary Response: - ROC Analysis: Determines optimal threshold classification - Sensitivity/Specificity: Balances true positive vs. false positive rates - PPV/NPV: Provides clinical utility measures - Statistical Significance: Confirms biomarker-response association
code: # Analyze biomarker expression for treatment response prediction biomarker_result_binary <- biomarkerresponse(   data = histopathology,   biomarker = "MeasurementA",   response = "Death",   responseType = "binary",   plotType = "boxplot",   showThreshold = TRUE,   thresholdMethod = "optimal",   performTests = TRUE,   showCorrelation = FALSE )  # View the results: print(biomarker_result_binary$threshold)        # Optimal threshold metrics print(biomarker_result_binary$groupComparison)  # Group statistics print(biomarker_result_binary$statisticalTests) # Statistical significance print(biomarker_result_binary$plot)             # Visualization

title: Biomarker Response Association Analysis - Comprehensive Guide for Precision Medicine
text: Analyzing biomarker levels correlate continuous treatment responses. Key Features Continuous Response: - Correlation Analysis: Quantifies strength biomarker-response relationship - Trend Lines: Visualizes dose-response curves - Confidence Intervals: Provides uncertainty estimates - Multiple Methods: Pearson linear, Spearman non-linear relationships
code: # Analyze biomarker correlation with continuous response biomarker_result_continuous <- biomarkerresponse(   data = treatmentResponse,   biomarker = "ResponseValue",  # Using as both biomarker and response for demo   response = "ResponseValue",   responseType = "continuous",   plotType = "scatter",   addTrendLine = TRUE,   trendMethod = "loess",   showCorrelation = TRUE,   performTests = TRUE )  # View correlation analysis print(biomarker_result_continuous$correlation)     # Pearson and Spearman correlations print(biomarker_result_continuous$statisticalTests) # Correlation significance

title: Biomarker Response Association Analysis - Comprehensive Guide for Precision Medicine
text: Analyzing biomarker differences across multiple response categories (CR/PR/SD/PD). Key Features Categorical Response: - Multiple Group Comparison: ANOVA parametric, Kruskal-Wallis non-parametric - Group Statistics: Mean, median, SD, IQR category - Effect Size: Quantifies magnitude differences groups - Post-hoc Analysis: Identifies groups differ significantly
code: # Analyze biomarker expression across response categories # First create categorical response from existing data histopathology_modified <- histopathology %>%   mutate(     Response_Category = case_when(       MeasurementA > quantile(MeasurementA, 0.75, na.rm = TRUE) ~ "Complete Response",       MeasurementA > quantile(MeasurementA, 0.50, na.rm = TRUE) ~ "Partial Response",        MeasurementA > quantile(MeasurementA, 0.25, na.rm = TRUE) ~ "Stable Disease",       TRUE ~ "Progressive Disease"     )   )  biomarker_result_categorical <- biomarkerresponse(   data = histopathology_modified,   biomarker = "MeasurementB",   response = "Response_Category",   responseType = "categorical",   plotType = "violin",   performTests = TRUE,   confidenceLevel = "0.95" )  # View group comparisons print(biomarker_result_categorical$groupComparison)  # Statistics by response group print(biomarker_result_categorical$statisticalTests) # ANOVA and Kruskal-Wallis tests

title: Biomarker Response Association Analysis - Comprehensive Guide for Precision Medicine
text: Finding optimal biomarker cutoff clinical decision-making. Threshold Selection Strategies: - ROC-Optimal: Maximizes Youden index (sensitivity + specificity - 1) - Clinical Cutoffs: Based established clinical guidelines - Percentile-Based: Uses data distribution (median, quartiles) - Manual: Specified based prior knowledge regulatory requirements
code: # Optimize biomarker threshold using ROC analysis biomarker_threshold_analysis <- biomarkerresponse(   data = histopathology,   biomarker = "MeasurementA",   response = "Outcome",   responseType = "binary",   plotType = "boxplot",   showThreshold = TRUE,   thresholdMethod = "optimal",  # ROC-based optimization   performTests = TRUE )  # Compare different threshold methods threshold_comparison <- list(   optimal = biomarkerresponse(data = histopathology, biomarker = "MeasurementA",                               response = "Outcome", thresholdMethod = "optimal"),   median = biomarkerresponse(data = histopathology, biomarker = "MeasurementA",                              response = "Outcome", thresholdMethod = "median"),   q75 = biomarkerresponse(data = histopathology, biomarker = "MeasurementA",                           response = "Outcome", thresholdMethod = "q75") )  # View threshold performance metrics print(biomarker_threshold_analysis$threshold)

title: Biomarker Response Association Analysis - Comprehensive Guide for Precision Medicine
text: Using biomarkers stratify patients different treatment approaches. Treatment Stratification Benefits: - Precision Dosing: Adjust treatment intensity based biomarker - Patient Selection: Identify candidates specific therapies - Combination Therapy: Optimize multi-drug regimens - Clinical Trial Design: Enrich responsive populations
code: # Analyze biomarker performance with treatment grouping biomarker_stratification <- biomarkerresponse(   data = histopathology,   biomarker = "MeasurementA",   response = "Death",   responseType = "binary",   groupVariable = "Group",  # Treatment arm stratification   plotType = "boxplot",   showThreshold = TRUE,   thresholdMethod = "optimal",   performTests = TRUE )  # View stratified analysis print(biomarker_stratification$groupComparison) print(biomarker_stratification$threshold) print(biomarker_stratification$plot)

previous_headings: Advanced Biomarker Analysis Techniques > Understanding Statistical Methods
title: Biomarker Response Association Analysis - Comprehensive Guide for Precision Medicine
text: Receiver Operating Characteristic analysis provides comprehensive biomarker performance assessment: AUC (Area Curve): Overall discriminative ability (0.5-1.0) Sensitivity: True positive rate (well identifies responders) Specificity: True negative rate (well identifies non-responders) PPV (Positive Predictive Value): Probability positive test indicates response NPV (Negative Predictive Value): Probability negative test indicates non-response AUC Interpretation: - 0.9-1.0: Excellent discrimination - 0.8-0.9: Good discrimination - 0.7-0.8: Fair discrimination - 0.6-0.7: Poor discrimination - 0.5-0.6: Fail (better chance)

previous_headings: Advanced Biomarker Analysis Techniques > Understanding Statistical Methods
what: Statistical Tests for Different Response Types
title: Biomarker Response Association Analysis - Comprehensive Guide for Precision Medicine
text: Binary Response: - T-test: Compares biomarker means responders/non-responders - Wilcoxon Rank-Sum: Non-parametric alternative non-normal data - Chi-square: Tests independence biomarker status response Categorical Response: - ANOVA: Compares biomarker means across multiple response groups - Kruskal-Wallis: Non-parametric alternative non-normal data - Post-hoc Tests: Identifies specific group differences Continuous Response: - Pearson Correlation: Linear relationship biomarker response - Spearman Correlation: Monotonic relationship (handles non-linear) - Linear Regression: Quantifies biomarker effect response

previous_headings: Advanced Biomarker Analysis Techniques > Advanced Interpretation Guidelines
title: Biomarker Response Association Analysis - Comprehensive Guide for Precision Medicine
text: Statistical Significance (p < 0.05): - Indicates unlikely occur chance - Affected sample size - May clinically meaningful Clinical Significance: - Meaningful difference patient outcomes - Considers effect size clinical context - Guides treatment decisions Effect Size Measures: - Cohen’s d: Standardized mean difference - Correlation coefficient: Strength linear relationship - Odds Ratio: Relative odds response biomarker positivity - Number Needed Treat: Patients needed treat one additional response

previous_headings: Advanced Biomarker Analysis Techniques > Advanced Interpretation Guidelines
title: Biomarker Response Association Analysis - Comprehensive Guide for Precision Medicine
text: Analytical Validation: - Accuracy: close true value - Precision: Reproducibility measurements - Sensitivity: Limit detection - Specificity: Freedom interference Clinical Validation: - Sensitivity/Specificity: Diagnostic performance - Positive/Negative Predictive Value: Clinical utility - Clinical Utility: Impact patient outcomes - Health Economics: Cost-effectiveness Regulatory Validation: - FDA/EMA guidelines compliance - Good Laboratory Practice (GLP) - Clinical Laboratory Improvement Amendments (CLIA) - ISO 15189 medical laboratory accreditation

title: Biomarker Response Association Analysis - Comprehensive Guide for Precision Medicine
code: # Simulate HER2 testing scenario her2_data <- data.frame(   patient_id = 1:200,   her2_expression = c(rlnorm(60, meanlog = 3, sdlog = 0.5),   # HER2+ patients                      rlnorm(140, meanlog = 1, sdlog = 0.8)),  # HER2- patients   trastuzumab_response = factor(c(rep("Responder", 45), rep("Non-responder", 15),                                  rep("Non-responder", 120), rep("Responder", 20))) )  her2_analysis <- biomarkerresponse(   data = her2_data,   biomarker = "her2_expression",   response = "trastuzumab_response",   responseType = "binary",   thresholdMethod = "optimal",   showThreshold = TRUE )  print(her2_analysis$threshold)

title: Biomarker Response Association Analysis - Comprehensive Guide for Precision Medicine
code: # Simulate PD-L1 expression analysis pdl1_data <- data.frame(   patient_id = 1:150,   pdl1_percentage = c(runif(50, 50, 95),     # High expressors                      runif(50, 1, 49),      # Low expressors                        rep(0, 50)),           # Negative   immunotherapy_response = factor(c(rep("Response", 35), rep("No Response", 15),                                    rep("Response", 15), rep("No Response", 35),                                    rep("Response", 5), rep("No Response", 45))) )  pdl1_analysis <- biomarkerresponse(   data = pdl1_data,   biomarker = "pdl1_percentage",    response = "immunotherapy_response",   responseType = "binary",   thresholdMethod = "manual",   thresholdValue = 50  # 50% cutoff commonly used )

title: Biomarker Response Association Analysis - Comprehensive Guide for Precision Medicine
code: # Simulate pharmacogenomic analysis pgx_data <- data.frame(   patient_id = 1:100,   cyp2d6_activity = factor(c(rep("Poor", 7), rep("Intermediate", 20),                              rep("Normal", 65), rep("Ultrarapid", 8))),   drug_clearance = c(rnorm(7, 2, 0.5),      # Poor metabolizers                     rnorm(20, 5, 1),        # Intermediate                     rnorm(65, 10, 2),       # Normal                     rnorm(8, 20, 3))        # Ultrarapid )  cyp2d6_analysis <- biomarkerresponse(   data = pgx_data,   biomarker = "drug_clearance",   response = "cyp2d6_activity",    responseType = "categorical",   plotType = "violin" )

title: Biomarker Response Association Analysis - Comprehensive Guide for Precision Medicine
code: # Simulate cardiac biomarker analysis cardiac_data <- data.frame(   patient_id = 1:300,   troponin_level = c(rlnorm(100, meanlog = 2, sdlog = 1),    # MI patients                     rlnorm(200, meanlog = -1, sdlog = 0.8)),  # Non-MI patients   mi_diagnosis = factor(c(rep("MI", 100), rep("No MI", 200))) )  troponin_analysis <- biomarkerresponse(   data = cardiac_data,   biomarker = "troponin_level",   response = "mi_diagnosis",   responseType = "binary",   thresholdMethod = "optimal",   logTransform = TRUE  # Troponin often log-transformed )

title: Biomarker Response Association Analysis - Comprehensive Guide for Precision Medicine
code: # Check for missing data patterns missing_summary <- function(data) {   missing_count <- sapply(data, function(x) sum(is.na(x)))   missing_percent <- round(missing_count / nrow(data) * 100, 2)      data.frame(     Variable = names(missing_count),     Missing_Count = missing_count,     Missing_Percent = missing_percent   ) }  missing_report <- missing_summary(histopathology) print(missing_report)  # Handle missing data before analysis # Complete case analysis (default in biomarkerresponse) # Or use imputation methods if appropriate

title: Biomarker Response Association Analysis - Comprehensive Guide for Precision Medicine
code: # Detect outliers using IQR method detect_outliers <- function(x) {   Q1 <- quantile(x, 0.25, na.rm = TRUE)   Q3 <- quantile(x, 0.75, na.rm = TRUE)   IQR <- Q3 - Q1   lower_bound <- Q1 - 1.5 * IQR   upper_bound <- Q3 + 1.5 * IQR      outliers <- which(x < lower_bound | x > upper_bound)   return(outliers) }  # Example with MeasurementA outliers <- detect_outliers(histopathology$MeasurementA) cat("Detected", length(outliers), "outliers in MeasurementA\n")  # Analysis with outlier removal biomarker_no_outliers <- biomarkerresponse(   data = histopathology,   biomarker = "MeasurementA",   response = "Death",   responseType = "binary",   outlierHandling = "remove"  # Remove outliers automatically )

title: Biomarker Response Association Analysis - Comprehensive Guide for Precision Medicine
code: # Log transformation for skewed biomarkers biomarker_log_transformed <- biomarkerresponse(   data = histopathology,   biomarker = "MeasurementA",   response = "Death",    responseType = "binary",   logTransform = TRUE  # Apply log(x+1) transformation )  # Compare original vs. transformed results original_analysis <- biomarkerresponse(   data = histopathology,   biomarker = "MeasurementA",    response = "Death",   responseType = "binary",   logTransform = FALSE )  # Log transformation often improves normality and reduces skewness

title: Biomarker Response Association Analysis - Comprehensive Guide for Precision Medicine
text: Problem: Dataset small reliable ROC analysis Solution: - Combine related datasets studies - Use simpler threshold methods (median, quartiles) - Consider descriptive analysis instead formal testing - Document sample size limitations

title: Biomarker Response Association Analysis - Comprehensive Guide for Precision Medicine
text: Problem: statistically significant biomarker-response relationship Solution: - Check data quality preprocessing - Consider non-linear relationships - Evaluate biomarker measurement methods - Assess clinical relevance despite statistical non-significance

what: High AUC but Low Clinical Utility
title: Biomarker Response Association Analysis - Comprehensive Guide for Precision Medicine
text: Problem: Good statistical performance limited clinical impact Solution: - Evaluate positive negative predictive values - Consider prevalence response population - Assess cost-effectiveness biomarker testing - Compare existing clinical criteria

title: Biomarker Response Association Analysis - Comprehensive Guide for Precision Medicine
text: Problem: Biomarker performance varies populations Solution: - Meta-analysis multiple studies - Subgroup analyses population characteristics - Standardization measurement methods - External validation independent cohorts

title: Biomarker Response Association Analysis - Comprehensive Guide for Precision Medicine
code: # Combine multiple biomarkers for improved prediction # Create composite biomarker score histopathology_composite <- histopathology %>%   mutate(     composite_score = scale(MeasurementA)[,1] + scale(MeasurementB)[,1] +                       scale(Grade)[,1]   )  composite_analysis <- biomarkerresponse(   data = histopathology_composite,   biomarker = "composite_score",   response = "Death",   responseType = "binary",   thresholdMethod = "optimal" )  print(composite_analysis$threshold)

title: Biomarker Response Association Analysis - Comprehensive Guide for Precision Medicine
code: # Cost-effectiveness analysis of biomarker testing cost_effectiveness_analysis <- function(sensitivity, specificity, prevalence,                                         cost_test, cost_treatment, benefit_treatment) {   # Calculate key metrics   ppv <- (sensitivity * prevalence) /           (sensitivity * prevalence + (1 - specificity) * (1 - prevalence))   npv <- (specificity * (1 - prevalence)) /           (specificity * (1 - prevalence) + (1 - sensitivity) * prevalence)      # Calculate costs and benefits   cost_per_test <- cost_test   unnecessary_treatments <- (1 - specificity) * (1 - prevalence)   missed_treatments <- (1 - sensitivity) * prevalence      net_benefit <- (sensitivity * prevalence * benefit_treatment) -                   (unnecessary_treatments * cost_treatment) - cost_test      return(list(     PPV = ppv,     NPV = npv,     Net_Benefit = net_benefit,     Cost_per_Test = cost_per_test   )) }  # Example calculation economics_result <- cost_effectiveness_analysis(   sensitivity = 0.85,   specificity = 0.80,    prevalence = 0.20,   cost_test = 500,   cost_treatment = 10000,   benefit_treatment = 50000 )  print(economics_result)

# Define variables for comprehensive assessment key_variables <- c("Age", "Grade", "TStage", "MeasurementA", "MeasurementB")  # Function to assess multiple variables assess_multiple_variables <- function(data, variables) {   results <- list()      for (var in variables) {     if (var %in% names(data)) {       cat("Assessing variable:", var, "
")              # Determine if numeric or categorical       is_numeric <- is.numeric(data[[var]])              results[[var]] <- checkdata(         data = data,         var = var,         showOutliers = is_numeric,         showDistribution = is_numeric,         showDuplicates = TRUE,         showPatterns = TRUE       )     }   }      return(results) }  # Perform comprehensive assessment comprehensive_assessment <- assess_multiple_variables(histopathology, key_variables)  # Summarize quality grades across variables for (var_name in names(comprehensive_assessment)) {   cat("Variable:", var_name, "

code: # Simulate MCAR scenario set.seed(123) n <- 200 data_mcar <- data.frame(   patient_id = 1:n,   measurement = rnorm(n, 50, 10),   outcome = rnorm(n, 100, 20) )  # Introduce random missing data (MCAR) missing_indices <- sample(1:n, 20)  # 10% random missing data_mcar$measurement[missing_indices] <- NA  # Assess quality mcar_quality <- checkdata(   data = data_mcar,   var = "measurement",   showPatterns = TRUE )  print("MCAR Pattern Assessment:") print(mcar_quality$patterns)

previous_headings: Advanced Data Quality Assessment > Missing Data Pattern Analysis
title: Data Quality Assessment - Comprehensive Guide for Clinical Research
code: # Simulate MAR scenario (missing depends on observed variables) data_mar <- data.frame(   patient_id = 1:200,   age = sample(20:80, 200, replace = TRUE),   measurement = rnorm(200, 50, 10) )  # Missing more likely in older patients (MAR) missing_prob <- plogis((data_mar$age - 60) / 10)  # Higher prob for older patients missing_mar <- rbinom(200, 1, missing_prob) data_mar$measurement[missing_mar == 1] <- NA  # Assess pattern mar_quality <- checkdata(   data = data_mar,   var = "measurement",   showPatterns = TRUE )

previous_headings: Advanced Data Quality Assessment > Missing Data Pattern Analysis
title: Data Quality Assessment - Comprehensive Guide for Clinical Research
code: # Simulate MNAR scenario (missing depends on unobserved value) data_mnar <- data.frame(   patient_id = 1:200,   measurement = rnorm(200, 50, 10) )  # High values more likely to be missing (MNAR) missing_prob_mnar <- plogis((data_mnar$measurement - 60) / 5) missing_mnar <- rbinom(200, 1, missing_prob_mnar) data_mnar$measurement[missing_mnar == 1] <- NA  # Assess pattern (will show concerning patterns) mnar_quality <- checkdata(   data = data_mnar,   var = "measurement",   showPatterns = TRUE )

# Function to recommend missing data strategy recommend_missing_strategy <- function(missing_pct, n_total, missing_pattern = "unknown") {      cat("MISSING DATA STRATEGY RECOMMENDATION
")   cat("=" %&% rep("=", 40) %&% "
")   cat("Missing percentage:", missing_pct, "%
")   cat("Total sample size:", n_total, "
")   cat("Missing pattern:", missing_pattern, "

")      if (missing_pct <= 5) {     cat("✅ RECOMMENDATION: Complete case analysis
")     cat("   - Missing data is minimal
")     cat("   - Unlikely to introduce significant bias
")     cat("   - Proceed with standard analysis
")        } else if (missing_pct <= 15 && n_total >= 100) {     cat("⚠️  RECOMMENDATION: Complete case analysis with sensitivity analysis
")     cat("   - Document missing data patterns
")     cat("   - Consider multiple imputation for sensitivity
")     cat("   - Compare results between methods
")        } else if (missing_pct <= 30 && missing_pattern == "MAR") {     cat("🔧 RECOMMENDATION: Multiple imputation
")     cat("   - Missing at random assumption reasonable
")     cat("   - Use multiple imputation (m=5-10)
")     cat("   - Include auxiliary variables
")     cat("   - Validate imputation model
")        } else {     cat("🚨 RECOMMENDATION: Investigate and consider additional data collection
")     cat("   - High missing data rate threatens validity
")     cat("   - Investigate missing data mechanisms
")     cat("   - Consider pattern-mixture models
")     cat("   - May need additional data collection
")   } }  # Example usage recommend_missing_strategy(missing_pct = 8, n_total = 150, missing_pattern = "MCAR") recommend_missing_strategy(missing_pct = 25, n_total = 200, missing_pattern = "MAR") recommend_missing_strategy(missing_pct = 40, n_total = 80, missing_pattern = "MNAR")

# Function to recommend outlier handling strategy recommend_outlier_strategy <- function(outlier_count, total_n, outlier_severity, clinical_context) {      outlier_pct <- 100 * outlier_count / total_n      cat("OUTLIER MANAGEMENT STRATEGY
")   cat("=" %&% rep("=", 30) %&% "
")   cat("Outliers detected:", outlier_count, "(", round(outlier_pct, 1), "%)
")   cat("Severity level:", outlier_severity, "
")   cat("Clinical context:", clinical_context, "

")      if (outlier_pct <= 2 && outlier_severity %in% c("High", "Very High")) {     cat("✅ RECOMMENDATION: Investigate and potentially retain
")     cat("   - Low outlier rate acceptable
")     cat("   - Verify data entry accuracy
")     cat("   - Check clinical plausibility
")     cat("   - Consider robust analysis methods
")        } else if (outlier_pct <= 5 && clinical_context == "biomarker") {     cat("⚠️  RECOMMENDATION: Detailed investigation required
")     cat("   - Biomarker data requires high precision
")     cat("   - Verify laboratory procedures
")     cat("   - Check sample handling
")     cat("   - Consider assay-specific thresholds
")        } else if (outlier_severity == "Extreme") {     cat("🔧 RECOMMENDATION: Exclude after documentation
")     cat("   - Extreme values likely data errors
")     cat("   - Document exclusion rationale
")     cat("   - Perform sensitivity analysis
")     cat("   - Report in methods section
")        } else {     cat("🚨 RECOMMENDATION: Comprehensive data audit
")     cat("   - High outlier rate indicates systematic issues
")     cat("   - Review data collection procedures
")     cat("   - Consider data transformation
")     cat("   - Validate measurement methods
")   } }  # Example usage scenarios recommend_outlier_strategy(3, 150, "High", "clinical_trial") recommend_outlier_strategy(8, 100, "Very High", "biomarker") recommend_outlier_strategy(15, 200, "Extreme", "patient_reported")

previous_headings: Quality Assurance Implementation > Automated Quality Monitoring
title: Data Quality Assessment - Comprehensive Guide for Clinical Research
code:
# Function to create quality monitoring dashboard create_quality_dashboard <- function(data, key_variables) {      dashboard_results <- data.frame(     Variable = character(),     Total_N = integer(),     Missing_Pct = numeric(),     Outlier_Count = integer(),     Quality_Grade = character(),     Action_Required = character(),     stringsAsFactors = FALSE   )      for (var in key_variables) {     if (var %in% names(data) && is.numeric(data[[var]])) {              # Basic quality metrics       total_n <- length(data[[var]])       missing_count <- sum(is.na(data[[var]]))       missing_pct <- 100 * missing_count / total_n              # Outlier detection       clean_data <- data[[var]][!is.na(data[[var]])]       if (length(clean_data) > 3) {         z_scores <- scale(clean_data)[,1]         outlier_count <- sum(abs(z_scores) > 3)       } else {         outlier_count <- 0       }              # Quality grading       if (missing_pct <= 5 && outlier_count <= 0.05 * length(clean_data)) {         grade <- "A"         action <- "None - Proceed"       } else if (missing_pct <= 15 && outlier_count <= 0.05 * length(clean_data)) {         grade <- "B"         action <- "Document limitations"       } else if (missing_pct <= 30) {         grade <- "C"         action <- "Data cleaning recommended"       } else {         grade <- "D"         action <- "Major intervention required"       }              # Add to dashboard       dashboard_results <- rbind(dashboard_results, data.frame(         Variable = var,         Total_N = total_n,         Missing_Pct = round(missing_pct, 1),         Outlier_Count = outlier_count,         Quality_Grade = grade,         Action_Required = action,         stringsAsFactors = FALSE       ))     }   }      return(dashboard_results) }  # Example dashboard for histopathology data key_vars <- c("Age", "Grade", "TStage", "MeasurementA", "MeasurementB") quality_dashboard <- create_quality_dashboard(histopathology, key_vars)  cat("📊 DATA QUALITY DASHBOARD
") cat("=" %&% rep("=", 50) %&% "
") print(quality_dashboard)  # Summary statistics grade_summary <- table(quality_dashboard$Quality_Grade) cat("
📈 QUALITY GRADE DISTRIBUTION:
") for (grade in names(grade_summary)) {   cat("Grade", grade, ":", grade_summary[grade], "variables
") }  # Action items action_needed <- quality_dashboard[quality_dashboard$Quality_Grade %in% c("C", "D"), ] if (nrow(action_needed) > 0) {   cat("
⚠️  VARIABLES REQUIRING ATTENTION:
")   print(action_needed[, c("Variable", "Quality_Grade", "Action_Required")]) }

")     }   }      # Section 5.1: Data Integrity   cat("🛡️  SECTION 5.1: DATA INTEGRITY (ALCOA+ PRINCIPLES)
")   cat("-" %&% rep("-", 45) %&% "
")      # Attributable, Legible, Contemporaneous, Original, Accurate   # + Complete, Consistent, Enduring, Available      overall_compliance <- TRUE   for (var in critical_variables) {     if (var %in% names(data)) {       missing_pct <- 100 * sum(is.na(data[[var]])) / nrow(data)              # Accuracy assessment (outlier rate)       if (is.numeric(data[[var]])) {         clean_data <- data[[var]][!is.na(data[[var]])]         if (length(clean_data) > 3) {           z_scores <- scale(clean_data)[,1]           outlier_rate <- sum(abs(z_scores) > 3) / length(clean_data)         } else {           outlier_rate <- 0         }       } else {         outlier_rate <- 0       }              # ALCOA+ Assessment       accurate <- outlier_rate <= 0.05       complete <- missing_pct <= 5              cat("Variable:", var, "
")       cat("  📊 Accurate:", ifelse(accurate, "✅ PASS", "❌ FAIL"),            "(outlier rate:", round(100*outlier_rate, 1), "%)
")       cat("  📋 Complete:", ifelse(complete, "✅ PASS", "❌ FAIL"),            "(missing:", round(missing_pct, 1), "%)
")              if (!accurate || !complete) {         overall_compliance <- FALSE       }       cat("
")     }   }      # Overall compliance summary   cat("📊 OVERALL COMPLIANCE STATUS
")   cat("=" %&% rep("=", 30) %&% "
")   if (overall_compliance) {     cat("✅ COMPLIANT: Data meets ICH E6 quality standards
")     cat("   Recommendation: Proceed with analysis
")   } else {     cat("❌ NON-COMPLIANT: Data quality issues identified
")     cat("   Recommendation: Address quality issues before analysis
")     cat("   Required Actions:
")     cat("   - Investigate root causes of data quality issues
")     cat("   - Implement corrective and preventive actions (CAPA)
")     cat("   - Document all data cleaning activities
")     cat("   - Obtain quality review approval before proceeding
")   }      return(compliance_report) }  # Example compliance assessment primary_vars <- c("Age", "MeasurementA") critical_vars <- c("Age", "Grade", "TStage", "MeasurementA", "Death")  compliance_results <- assess_gcp_compliance(   data = histopathology,   primary_endpoints = primary_vars,   critical_variables = critical_vars )

title: Data Quality Assessment - Comprehensive Guide for Clinical Research
text: Problem: >20% missing data primary endpoint Root Causes: - Systematic measurement failures - Patient dropout patterns - Data collection protocol issues - Technical measurement problems Resolution Strategy:
code:
# Systematic approach to missing data investigation investigate_missing_data <- function(data, variable) {      cat("🔍 MISSING DATA INVESTIGATION PROTOCOL
")   cat("=" %&% rep("=", 40) %&% "
")      missing_indices <- which(is.na(data[[variable]]))   missing_pct <- 100 * length(missing_indices) / nrow(data)      cat("Variable:", variable, "
")   cat("Missing count:", length(missing_indices), "
")   cat("Missing percentage:", round(missing_pct, 1), "%

")      # Step 1: Pattern analysis   cat("STEP 1: MISSING DATA PATTERN ANALYSIS
")   cat("-" %&% rep("-", 35) %&% "
")      if (missing_pct > 50) {     cat("⚠️  SEVERE: >50% missing - systematic failure likely
")     cat("   Action: Investigate data collection procedures
")   } else if (missing_pct > 20) {     cat("⚠️  HIGH: >20% missing - potential systematic issues
")     cat("   Action: Analyze missing data patterns
")   } else {     cat("✅ ACCEPTABLE: <20% missing
")   }      # Step 2: Temporal pattern check (if date variable available)   if ("SurgeryDate" %in% names(data) || "LastFollowUpDate" %in% names(data)) {     cat("
STEP 2: TEMPORAL PATTERN ANALYSIS
")     cat("-" %&% rep("-", 30) %&% "
")     cat("   Recommendation: Plot missing data over time
")     cat("   Look for: Equipment failures, staff changes, protocol amendments
")   }      # Step 3: Subgroup analysis   cat("
STEP 3: SUBGROUP MISSING DATA ANALYSIS
")   cat("-" %&% rep("-", 35) %&% "
")      if ("Group" %in% names(data)) {     group_missing <- aggregate(is.na(data[[variable]]),                                by = list(Group = data$Group),                                FUN = function(x) 100 * mean(x))     names(group_missing)[2] <- "Missing_Pct"          cat("Missing data by group:
")     print(group_missing)          max_diff <- max(group_missing$Missing_Pct) - min(group_missing$Missing_Pct)     if (max_diff > 10) {       cat("⚠️  WARNING: >10% difference between groups
")       cat("   Potential differential missing data mechanisms
")     }   }      # Step 4: Recommendations   cat("
STEP 4: RECOMMENDED ACTIONS
")   cat("-" %&% rep("-", 25) %&% "
")      if (missing_pct > 30) {     cat("🚨 IMMEDIATE ACTIONS REQUIRED:
")     cat("   1. Halt further data collection pending investigation
")     cat("   2. Review and revise data collection procedures
")     cat("   3. Retrain data collection staff
")     cat("   4. Consider protocol amendment
")   } else if (missing_pct > 15) {     cat("⚠️  CORRECTIVE ACTIONS RECOMMENDED:
")     cat("   1. Investigate root causes
")     cat("   2. Implement process improvements
")     cat("   3. Increase monitoring frequency
")     cat("   4. Document corrective actions
")   } else {     cat("✅ MONITORING ACTIONS:
")     cat("   1. Continue routine monitoring
")     cat("   2. Document acceptable missing data rate
")     cat("   3. Plan appropriate analysis methods
")   } }  # Example investigation investigate_missing_data(histopathology, "MeasurementA")

title: Data Quality Assessment - Comprehensive Guide for Clinical Research
text: Problem: Multiple extreme values suggesting measurement issues Solution Framework:
code:
# Systematic outlier investigation protocol investigate_outlier_patterns <- function(data, variable) {      cat("🎯 OUTLIER PATTERN INVESTIGATION
")   cat("=" %&% rep("=", 35) %&% "
")      clean_data <- data[[variable]][!is.na(data[[variable]])]   z_scores <- scale(clean_data)[,1]   outlier_indices <- which(abs(z_scores) > 3)   outlier_rate <- length(outlier_indices) / length(clean_data)      cat("Variable:", variable, "
")   cat("Outlier count:", length(outlier_indices), "
")   cat("Outlier rate:", round(100 * outlier_rate, 1), "%

")      # Pattern analysis   if (outlier_rate > 0.1) {     cat("🚨 SYSTEMATIC ISSUE DETECTED
")     cat("   >10% outlier rate suggests measurement problems
")          # Check for clustering     outlier_values <- clean_data[outlier_indices]     if (length(unique(round(outlier_values))) < length(outlier_values) * 0.5) {       cat("   PATTERN: Clustered outliers - possible systematic error
")       cat("   ACTION: Check calibration and measurement procedures
")     }          # Check for extreme values     extreme_outliers <- sum(abs(z_scores) > 4)     if (extreme_outliers > 0) {       cat("   PATTERN:", extreme_outliers, "extreme outliers (|z| > 4)
")       cat("   ACTION: Verify data entry and instrument function
")     }        } else if (outlier_rate > 0.05) {     cat("⚠️  ELEVATED OUTLIER RATE
")     cat("   5-10% outlier rate requires investigation
")     cat("   ACTION: Review measurement protocol consistency
")        } else {     cat("✅ ACCEPTABLE OUTLIER RATE
")     cat("   <5% outlier rate is within normal range
")   }      # Recommendations based on pattern   cat("
RECOMMENDATIONS:
")   if (outlier_rate > 0.1) {     cat("1. Immediate equipment calibration check
")     cat("2. Staff retraining on measurement procedures
")     cat("3. Implement additional quality control measures
")     cat("4. Consider excluding outliers with documentation
")   } else {     cat("1. Individual outlier review and verification
")     cat("2. Clinical plausibility assessment
")     cat("3. Consider robust analysis methods
")     cat("4. Document outlier handling approach
")   } }  # Example outlier investigation investigate_outlier_patterns(histopathology, "MeasurementA")

previous_headings: Advanced Quality Assessment Topics > Machine Learning Quality Assessment
title: Data Quality Assessment - Comprehensive Guide for Clinical Research
code:
# Advanced quality scoring using multiple metrics calculate_composite_quality_score <- function(data, variable) {      # Initialize score components   scores <- list()      # Completeness score (0-100)   missing_pct <- 100 * sum(is.na(data[[variable]])) / length(data[[variable]])   scores$completeness <- max(0, 100 - missing_pct)      # Accuracy score (based on outlier rate)   if (is.numeric(data[[variable]])) {     clean_data <- data[[variable]][!is.na(data[[variable]])]     if (length(clean_data) > 3) {       z_scores <- scale(clean_data)[,1]       outlier_rate <- sum(abs(z_scores) > 3) / length(clean_data)       scores$accuracy <- max(0, 100 - (outlier_rate * 1000))  # Penalize outliers heavily     } else {       scores$accuracy <- 50  # Insufficient data     }   } else {     scores$accuracy <- 100  # Categorical data, different accuracy assessment needed   }      # Consistency score (based on variability)   if (is.numeric(data[[variable]])) {     clean_data <- data[[variable]][!is.na(data[[variable]])]     if (length(clean_data) > 1 && mean(clean_data) != 0) {       cv <- abs(sd(clean_data) / mean(clean_data)) * 100       # Optimal CV depends on measurement type, using general threshold       if (cv < 15) {         scores$consistency <- 100       } else if (cv < 30) {         scores$consistency <- 100 - ((cv - 15) * 2)  # Linear decrease       } else {         scores$consistency <- max(0, 70 - cv)       }     } else {       scores$consistency <- 0  # No variability or zero mean     }   } else {     # For categorical, assess balance     freq_table <- table(data[[variable]], useNA = "no")     if (length(freq_table) > 1) {       balance_ratio <- min(freq_table) / max(freq_table)       scores$consistency <- balance_ratio * 100     } else {       scores$consistency <- 0  # Only one category     }   }      # Precision score (based on unique values)   clean_data <- data[[variable]][!is.na(data[[variable]])]   unique_pct <- length(unique(clean_data)) / length(clean_data) * 100   if (unique_pct > 95) {     scores$precision <- 100   } else if (unique_pct > 50) {     scores$precision <- 50 + (unique_pct - 50)   } else {     scores$precision <- unique_pct   }      # Calculate weighted composite score   weights <- c(completeness = 0.3, accuracy = 0.3, consistency = 0.2, precision = 0.2)   composite_score <- sum(unlist(scores) * weights)      # Convert to letter grade   if (composite_score >= 90) {     grade <- "A"   } else if (composite_score >= 80) {     grade <- "B"   } else if (composite_score >= 70) {     grade <- "C"   } else {     grade <- "D"   }      return(list(     scores = scores,     composite_score = round(composite_score, 1),     grade = grade   )) }  # Example advanced scoring advanced_score <- calculate_composite_quality_score(histopathology, "Age") cat("ADVANCED QUALITY ASSESSMENT
") cat("=" %&% rep("=", 30) %&% "
") cat("Completeness:", round(advanced_score$scores$completeness, 1), "
") cat("Accuracy:", round(advanced_score$scores$accuracy, 1), "
") cat("Consistency:", round(advanced_score$scores$consistency, 1), "
") cat("Precision:", round(advanced_score$scores$precision, 1), "
") cat("Composite Score:", advanced_score$composite_score, "
") cat("Quality Grade:", advanced_score$grade, "
")

code: # Calculate missing data percentages missing_summary <- histopathology %>%   summarise_all(~sum(is.na(.))) %>%   pivot_longer(everything(), names_to = "Variable", values_to = "Missing_Count") %>%   mutate(     Missing_Percentage = round(Missing_Count / nrow(histopathology) * 100, 1),     Data_Quality = case_when(       Missing_Percentage == 0 ~ "Complete",       Missing_Percentage <= 5 ~ "Excellent",        Missing_Percentage <= 10 ~ "Good",       Missing_Percentage <= 20 ~ "Acceptable",       TRUE ~ "Poor"     )   ) %>%   arrange(desc(Missing_Percentage))  # Display missing data summary kable(missing_summary %>% filter(Missing_Count > 0),       caption = "Missing Data Summary",       col.names = c("Variable", "Missing Count", "Missing %", "Quality Rating"))

title: Summarising Clinicopathological Data
text: summarydata() provides descriptive statistics (mean, median, quartiles) numeric variables.
code: summarydata(   data = histopathology,   vars = vars(Age, TumorSize) )

title: Summarising Clinicopathological Data
text: reportcat() summarises categorical variables counts percentages.
code: reportcat(   data = histopathology,   vars = vars(Sex, Grade) )

title: Summarising Clinicopathological Data
text: Use crosstable() create cross tabulations statistical tests. group argument defines column variable.
code: crosstable(   data = histopathology,   vars = vars(Sex, Grade),   group = "PreinvasiveComponent",   sty = "nejm",   excl = TRUE )

title: Summarising Clinicopathological Data
text: tableone() creates publication-ready tables baseline characteristics. functions output results objects contain tables can converted data frames customisation.
code: tableone(   data = histopathology,   vars = vars(Sex, PreinvasiveComponent, LVI, PNI, Grade, Age),   sty = "t3",   excl = TRUE )

title: Benford's Law Analysis - Comprehensive Guide for Data Validation and Fraud Detection
text: Benford’s Law, also known Newcomb-Benford Law First-Digit Law, fascinating mathematical phenomenon describes frequency distribution leading digits many naturally occurring datasets. law become invaluable tool fraud detection, data validation, quality assurance across diverse fields.

previous_headings: Introduction to Benford’s Law > What is Benford’s Law?
title: Benford's Law Analysis - Comprehensive Guide for Data Validation and Fraud Detection
text: Benford’s Law states many naturally occurring collections numbers, leading digit d (d ∈ {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9}) occurs probability: P(d) = log₁₀(1 + 1/d) gives us following expected frequencies: - Digit 1: 30.1% - Digit 2: 17.6% - Digit 3: 12.5% - Digit 4: 9.7% - Digit 5: 7.9% - Digit 6: 6.7% - Digit 7: 5.8% - Digit 8: 5.1% - Digit 9: 4.6%

previous_headings: Introduction to Benford’s Law > What is Benford’s Law?
title: Benford's Law Analysis - Comprehensive Guide for Data Validation and Fraud Detection
text: 1881: Astronomer Simon Newcomb first observed pattern 1938: Physicist Frank Benford rediscovered systematically studied 1995: Theodore Hill provided mathematical proof Today: Widely used forensic accounting, fraud detection, data validation

previous_headings: Introduction to Benford’s Law > When Does Benford’s Law Apply?
title: Benford's Law Analysis - Comprehensive Guide for Data Validation and Fraud Detection
text: Benford’s Law works best datasets : Span multiple orders magnitude (e.g., hundreds millions) Result natural processes (artificially constrained) assigned fabricated numbers sufficient sample size (typically 100+ observations) positive real numbers (zeros, negatives, assigned IDs)

previous_headings: Introduction to Benford’s Law > When Does Benford’s Law Apply?
title: Benford's Law Analysis - Comprehensive Guide for Data Validation and Fraud Detection
text: Financial: Transaction amounts, revenues, stock prices Geographic: Population sizes, river lengths, mountain heights Scientific: Physical constants, measurement data, citation counts Economic: GDP figures, market capitalizations, trade volumes Natural: Earthquake magnitudes, species populations, physical measurements

previous_headings: Introduction to Benford’s Law > When Does Benford’s Law Apply?
title: Benford's Law Analysis - Comprehensive Guide for Data Validation and Fraud Detection
text: Assigned numbers: Social security numbers, phone numbers, zip codes Constrained ranges: Age (limited ~0-120), test scores (0-100) Artificial data: Lottery numbers, dice rolls Manipulated data: Fabricated financial records, expense fraud

title: Benford's Law Analysis - Comprehensive Guide for Data Validation and Fraud Detection
text: Benford analysis workflow jamovi follows steps: Data Selection: Choose appropriate numeric variables Benford Analysis: Apply statistical tests visualization Interpretation: Assess compliance identify anomalies Investigation: Follow suspicious patterns Validation: Confirm findings additional analysis

title: Benford's Law Analysis - Comprehensive Guide for Data Validation and Fraud Detection
text: Financial transaction data naturally follows Benford’s Law due wide range amounts natural business processes. Key Benford Characteristics Financial Data: - Natural distribution: Transaction amounts arise diverse business activities - Multiple magnitudes: small purchases large investments - Economic processes: Market forces create natural distributions - Compliance expected: Well-managed businesses show Benford compliance
code: # Analyze transaction amounts - should follow Benford's Law benford_result_financial <- benford(   data = financial_data,   var = "transaction_amounts" )  # View the results: print(benford_result_financial$text)    # Statistical analysis print(benford_result_financial$text2)   # Suspect identification print(benford_result_financial$plot)    # Visualization

title: Benford's Law Analysis - Comprehensive Guide for Data Validation and Fraud Detection
text: Manipulated financial data often violates Benford’s Law systematic patterns introduced fraudsters. Common Fraud Patterns Detected: - Excessive rounding: many round numbers (100, 200, 500) - Threshold avoidance: Amounts just authorization limits - Digit avoidance: Systematic avoidance certain first digits - Clustering: Psychological barriers repeated amounts - Copy-paste errors: Identical amounts across multiple entries
code: # Analyze suspicious expense claims - likely to violate Benford's Law benford_result_fraud <- benford(   data = fraudulent_data,   var = "suspicious_expenses" )  # Compare with procurement fraud patterns benford_result_procurement <- benford(   data = fraudulent_data,   var = "procurement_amounts" )  # View fraud indicators print(benford_result_fraud$text) print(benford_result_fraud$text2)

title: Benford's Law Analysis - Comprehensive Guide for Data Validation and Fraud Detection
text: Geographic natural data provides textbook examples Benford’s Law action. Natural Data Follows Benford’s Law: - Scale invariance: Natural processes independent human measurement units - Multiplicative processes: Growth decay processes create log-normal distributions - Power laws: Many natural phenomena follow power-law distributions - artificial constraints: Nature doesn’t “round” convenient numbers
code: # Analyze city populations - classic Benford example benford_result_populations <- benford(   data = natural_phenomena_data,   var = "city_populations" )  # Analyze river lengths - natural geographic data benford_result_rivers <- benford(   data = natural_phenomena_data,   var = "river_lengths" )  # Analyze earthquake magnitudes (scaled) benford_result_earthquakes <- benford(   data = natural_phenomena_data,   var = "earthquake_magnitudes_scaled" )

title: Benford's Law Analysis - Comprehensive Guide for Data Validation and Fraud Detection
text: Research data quality can assessed using Benford analysis detect potential data fabrication systematic errors. Research Data Quality Indicators: - Fabricated data: Often shows uniform digit distribution - Measurement bias: Systematic rounding preferred numbers - Data entry errors: Clustering around convenient values - Copy-paste errors: Repeated values across studies
code: # Analyze experimental measurements benford_result_experiments <- benford(   data = scientific_data,   var = "experimental_values" )  # Analyze sample sizes - should follow power law benford_result_samples <- benford(   data = scientific_data,   var = "sample_sizes" )  # Analyze funding amounts benford_result_funding <- benford(   data = scientific_data,   var = "funding_amounts" )

title: Benford's Law Analysis - Comprehensive Guide for Data Validation and Fraud Detection
text: Economic indicators market data demonstrate Benford’s Law macroeconomic contexts.
code: # Analyze GDP figures - economic scale data benford_result_gdp <- benford(   data = economic_data,   var = "gdp_millions" )  # Analyze market capitalizations benford_result_market <- benford(   data = economic_data,   var = "market_cap_thousands" )  # Analyze trade volumes benford_result_trade <- benford(   data = economic_data,   var = "trade_volumes" )

previous_headings: Advanced Benford Analysis Techniques > Understanding Statistical Tests
title: Benford's Law Analysis - Comprehensive Guide for Data Validation and Fraud Detection
text: primary statistical test Benford compliance: Null hypothesis: Data follows Benford’s Law Test statistic: χ² = Σ[(Observed - Expected)² / Expected] Degrees freedom: 8 (9 digits - 1) Significance level: Typically α = 0.05 0.01 Interpretation: - p > 0.05: Data consistent Benford’s Law - p < 0.05: Significant deviation Benford’s Law - p < 0.01: Strong evidence Benford compliance

previous_headings: Advanced Benford Analysis Techniques > Understanding Statistical Tests
title: Benford's Law Analysis - Comprehensive Guide for Data Validation and Fraud Detection
text: Alternative measure Benford compliance: MAD = (1/9) × Σ|Observed% - Expected%| Excellent compliance: MAD < 0.006 Acceptable compliance: 0.006 ≤ MAD < 0.012 Marginal compliance: 0.012 ≤ MAD < 0.015 Non-compliance: MAD ≥ 0.015

previous_headings: Advanced Benford Analysis Techniques > Digit Analysis Beyond First Digit
title: Benford's Law Analysis - Comprehensive Guide for Data Validation and Fraud Detection
text: Second digits (0-9) follow different pattern: - uniform distribution first digits - P(d) = Σ log₁₀(1 + 1/(10k + d)) k = 1 9 - Useful detecting sophisticated manipulation

previous_headings: Advanced Benford Analysis Techniques > Digit Analysis Beyond First Digit
title: Benford's Law Analysis - Comprehensive Guide for Data Validation and Fraud Detection
text: Combinations 10-99 provide granular detection: - 90 possible combinations - Higher statistical power large datasets - Better detection subtle manipulations

previous_headings: Advanced Benford Analysis Techniques > Fraud Detection Methodology
title: Benford's Law Analysis - Comprehensive Guide for Data Validation and Fraud Detection
text: Significant χ² test (p < 0.05) High MAD values (> 0.015) Unusual digit distribution patterns Excessive round numbers Clustering around thresholds Avoidance specific digits uniform distributions Data type inappropriate Benford Recent data manipulation allegations Internal control weaknesses

code: # Step 1: Initial Benford analysis initial_analysis <- benford(data = suspicious_dataset, var = "amounts")  # Step 2: Examine suspects suspects <- initial_analysis$text2 high_risk_items <- suspects[suspects$risk_score > threshold]  # Step 3: Follow-up analysis # - Analyze by time period # - Analyze by employee/department   # - Analyze by amount ranges # - Second digit analysis # - Cross-reference with other data  # Step 4: Document findings # - Statistical evidence # - Pattern descriptions # - Risk assessment # - Recommendations

title: Benford's Law Analysis - Comprehensive Guide for Data Validation and Fraud Detection
text: Strong Compliance (p > 0.10, MAD < 0.006): - Data likely natural unmanipulated - Low fraud risk - High data quality confidence Moderate Compliance (0.05 < p < 0.10, 0.006 < MAD < 0.012): - Generally acceptable compliance - Minor deviations may explainable - Monitor patterns Weak Compliance (0.01 < p < 0.05, 0.012 < MAD < 0.015): - Significant deviation Benford - Investigate underlying causes - Potential data quality issues Non-Compliance (p < 0.01, MAD > 0.015): - Strong evidence Benford - High priority investigation - Possible fraud manipulation

title: Benford's Law Analysis - Comprehensive Guide for Data Validation and Fraud Detection
text: Legitimate Reasons: - Data doesn’t meet Benford conditions - Small sample size - Constrained number ranges - Industry-specific patterns Concerning Reasons: - Data manipulation fraud - Systematic fabrication - Copy-paste errors - Inadequate internal controls

title: Benford's Law Analysis - Comprehensive Guide for Data Validation and Fraud Detection
code: # Automated Benford monitoring system benford_monitor <- function(dataset, var_name, threshold = 0.05) {   result <- benford(data = dataset, var = var_name)      # Alert system   if (result$p_value < threshold) {     alert <- list(       timestamp = Sys.time(),       dataset = deparse(substitute(dataset)),       variable = var_name,       p_value = result$p_value,       risk_level = if (result$p_value < 0.01) "HIGH" else "MEDIUM"     )          # Log alert and notify stakeholders     return(alert)   }      return(NULL) }

title: ClinicoPath Descriptives 04: Data Quality Assessment for Clinical Research
text: Data quality assessment fundamental reliable clinical research. vignette demonstrates comprehensive data exploration quality assessment techniques using ClinicoPathDescriptives, including missing data analysis, distribution assessment, outlier detection, fraud detection using Benford’s law.

title: ClinicoPath Descriptives 04: Data Quality Assessment for Clinical Research
text: Completeness: Presence missing data Consistency: Logical relationships variables Accuracy: Conformance expected patterns Validity: Adherence defined formats ranges Integrity: Referential business rule compliance
code:
library(ClinicoPathDescriptives) library(dplyr) library(tidyr) library(ggplot2) library(knitr)  # Load the dataset data(histopathology)  # Initial data overview cat("Dataset Dimensions:", dim(histopathology), "
") cat("Variables:", ncol(histopathology), "
") cat("Observations:", nrow(histopathology), "

")  # Variable types overview str(histopathology, give.attr = FALSE)

title: ClinicoPath Descriptives 04: Data Quality Assessment for Clinical Research
code: # Calculate missing data percentages missing_summary <- histopathology %>%   summarise_all(~sum(is.na(.))) %>%   pivot_longer(everything(), names_to = "Variable", values_to = "Missing_Count") %>%   mutate(     Missing_Percentage = round(Missing_Count / nrow(histopathology) * 100, 1),     Data_Quality = case_when(       Missing_Percentage == 0 ~ "Complete",       Missing_Percentage <= 5 ~ "Excellent",        Missing_Percentage <= 10 ~ "Good",       Missing_Percentage <= 20 ~ "Acceptable",       TRUE ~ "Poor"     )   ) %>%   arrange(desc(Missing_Percentage))  # Display missing data summary kable(missing_summary %>% filter(Missing_Count > 0),       caption = "Missing Data Summary",       col.names = c("Variable", "Missing Count", "Missing %", "Quality Rating"))

title: ClinicoPath Descriptives 04: Data Quality Assessment for Clinical Research
code: # Analyze completeness by variable groups demographic_vars <- c("Age", "Sex", "Race") pathology_vars <- c("Grade", "TStage", "LVI", "PNI", "LymphNodeMetastasis") biomarker_vars <- c("MeasurementA", "MeasurementB", "Anti-X-intensity", "Anti-Y-intensity") outcome_vars <- c("Outcome", "Death", "OverallTime", "Mortality5yr")  # Function to calculate completeness for variable groups assess_completeness <- function(data, vars, group_name) {   if(all(vars %in% names(data))) {     completeness <- data %>%       select(all_of(vars)) %>%       summarise_all(~sum(!is.na(.))) %>%       pivot_longer(everything(), names_to = "Variable", values_to = "Complete_Count") %>%       mutate(         Group = group_name,         Completeness_Rate = round(Complete_Count / nrow(data) * 100, 1)       )     return(completeness)   }   return(NULL) }  # Assess each variable group completeness_by_group <- bind_rows(   assess_completeness(histopathology, demographic_vars, "Demographics"),   assess_completeness(histopathology, pathology_vars, "Pathology"),   assess_completeness(histopathology, biomarker_vars, "Biomarkers"),   assess_completeness(histopathology, outcome_vars, "Outcomes") ) %>%   filter(!is.null(.))  # Summary by group group_summary <- completeness_by_group %>%   group_by(Group) %>%   summarise(     Variables = n(),     Mean_Completeness = round(mean(Completeness_Rate), 1),     Min_Completeness = round(min(Completeness_Rate), 1),     .groups = 'drop'   )  kable(group_summary,       caption = "Data Completeness by Variable Group",       col.names = c("Variable Group", "Variables", "Mean Completeness (%)", "Min Completeness (%)"))

title: ClinicoPath Descriptives 04: Data Quality Assessment for Clinical Research
code:
# Analyze distributions of continuous variables continuous_vars <- c("Age", "OverallTime", "MeasurementA", "MeasurementB")  # Check which variables exist in the dataset available_vars <- continuous_vars[continuous_vars %in% names(histopathology)] if(length(available_vars) > 0) {   tryCatch({     summarydata(       data = histopathology,       vars = available_vars,       date_vars = NULL,       grvar = NULL     )   }, error = function(e) {     cat("Error with summarydata:", conditionMessage(e), "
")     cat("Available continuous variables:", paste(available_vars, collapse = ", "), "
")     cat("Variable types:
")     print(sapply(histopathology[available_vars], class))   }) } else {   cat("No continuous variables found in dataset
") }

title: ClinicoPath Descriptives 04: Data Quality Assessment for Clinical Research
text: Benford’s law states naturally occurring datasets, leading digit 1 appears 30.1% time, digit 2 17.6%, . Deviation pattern may indicate data fabrication.

title: ClinicoPath Descriptives 04: Data Quality Assessment for Clinical Research
code:
# Create synthetic financial data suitable for Benford analysis # Financial amounts typically span multiple orders of magnitude set.seed(123) financial_data <- data.frame(   ID = 1:250,   FinancialAmount = round(exp(rnorm(250, mean = 7, sd = 2)), 2) )  # Display data characteristics for Benford analysis cat("Financial data summary:
") print(summary(financial_data$FinancialAmount)) cat("
Range ratio (should be > 10 for Benford's Law):",      max(financial_data$FinancialAmount)/min(financial_data$FinancialAmount), "
") cat("Sample size:", nrow(financial_data), "
")  # Note: Benford analysis would be performed here # benford(data = financial_data, var = "FinancialAmount") cat("
Benford's Law Analysis:
") cat("This dataset would be suitable for Benford analysis due to:
") cat("- Large range ratio (>", round(max(financial_data$FinancialAmount)/min(financial_data$FinancialAmount)), "x)
") cat("- Sufficient sample size (n =", nrow(financial_data), ")
") cat("- Naturally occurring positive values
")

title: ClinicoPath Descriptives 04: Data Quality Assessment for Clinical Research
code:
# Create synthetic expense data with potential anomalies set.seed(456) expense_data <- data.frame(   ID = 1:250,   ExpenseAmount = c(     round(exp(rnorm(230, mean = 6, sd = 1.5)), 2),  # Natural expenses     rep(c(1000, 5000, 10000), c(7, 7, 6))  # Suspicious round numbers   ) )  # Display data characteristics cat("Expense data summary:
") print(summary(expense_data$ExpenseAmount)) cat("
Suspicious round numbers analysis:
") round_numbers <- expense_data$ExpenseAmount[expense_data$ExpenseAmount %in% c(1000, 5000, 10000)] cat("Number of suspicious round amounts:", length(round_numbers), "
") cat("Percentage of suspicious entries:", round(length(round_numbers)/nrow(expense_data)*100, 1), "%
")  # Note: Benford analysis would be performed here # benford(data = expense_data, var = "ExpenseAmount") cat("
Benford's Law Analysis Indicators:
") cat("- Presence of suspicious round numbers suggests potential manipulation
") cat("- High frequency of amounts ending in 000 may indicate fraud
") cat("- Range ratio:", round(max(expense_data$ExpenseAmount)/min(expense_data$ExpenseAmount)), "x (suitable for Benford)
")

title: ClinicoPath Descriptives 04: Data Quality Assessment for Clinical Research
code:
# Analyze inter-rater reliability data rater_vars <- histopathology %>%   select(starts_with("Rater")) %>%   names()  if(length(rater_vars) > 0) {   # Binary rater variables   binary_raters <- rater_vars[grepl("[0-9]$", rater_vars)]   if(length(binary_raters) > 0) {     tryCatch({       reportcat(         data = histopathology,         vars = binary_raters[1:min(3, length(binary_raters))]       )     }, error = function(e) {       cat("Error with binary raters reportcat:", conditionMessage(e), "
")       cat("Binary rater variables:", paste(binary_raters, collapse = ", "), "
")     })   } else {     cat("No binary rater variables found (ending with digits)
")   }      # Categorical rater variables     categorical_raters <- rater_vars[grepl("[A-Z]$", rater_vars)]   if(length(categorical_raters) > 0) {     tryCatch({       reportcat(         data = histopathology,         vars = categorical_raters       )     }, error = function(e) {       cat("Error with categorical raters reportcat:", conditionMessage(e), "
")       cat("Categorical rater variables:", paste(categorical_raters, collapse = ", "), "
")     })   } else {     cat("No categorical rater variables found (ending with letters)
")   } } else {   cat("No rater variables found in dataset
") }

title: ClinicoPath Descriptives 04: Data Quality Assessment for Clinical Research
code: # Identify potential outliers in continuous variables outlier_analysis <- histopathology %>%   select(Age, OverallTime, MeasurementA, MeasurementB) %>%   summarise_all(     list(       Mean = ~round(mean(., na.rm = TRUE), 2),       SD = ~round(sd(., na.rm = TRUE), 2),       Q1 = ~round(quantile(., 0.25, na.rm = TRUE), 2),       Q3 = ~round(quantile(., 0.75, na.rm = TRUE), 2),       IQR = ~round(IQR(., na.rm = TRUE), 2),       Lower_Fence = ~round(quantile(., 0.25, na.rm = TRUE) - 1.5 * IQR(., na.rm = TRUE), 2),       Upper_Fence = ~round(quantile(., 0.75, na.rm = TRUE) + 1.5 * IQR(., na.rm = TRUE), 2)     )   ) %>%   pivot_longer(everything(), names_to = "Stat", values_to = "Value") %>%   separate(Stat, into = c("Variable", "Statistic"), sep = "_", extra = "merge") %>%   pivot_wider(names_from = Statistic, values_from = Value)  kable(outlier_analysis,       caption = "Outlier Detection Statistics",       digits = 2)

title: ClinicoPath Descriptives 04: Data Quality Assessment for Clinical Research
code: # Count extreme values beyond fences extreme_values <- histopathology %>%   summarise(     Age_Low_Outliers = sum(Age < (quantile(Age, 0.25, na.rm = TRUE) - 1.5 * IQR(Age, na.rm = TRUE)), na.rm = TRUE),     Age_High_Outliers = sum(Age > (quantile(Age, 0.75, na.rm = TRUE) + 1.5 * IQR(Age, na.rm = TRUE)), na.rm = TRUE),     Time_Low_Outliers = sum(OverallTime < (quantile(OverallTime, 0.25, na.rm = TRUE) - 1.5 * IQR(OverallTime, na.rm = TRUE)), na.rm = TRUE),     Time_High_Outliers = sum(OverallTime > (quantile(OverallTime, 0.75, na.rm = TRUE) + 1.5 * IQR(OverallTime, na.rm = TRUE)), na.rm = TRUE),     MeasA_Low_Outliers = sum(MeasurementA < (quantile(MeasurementA, 0.25, na.rm = TRUE) - 1.5 * IQR(MeasurementA, na.rm = TRUE)), na.rm = TRUE),     MeasA_High_Outliers = sum(MeasurementA > (quantile(MeasurementA, 0.75, na.rm = TRUE) + 1.5 * IQR(MeasurementA, na.rm = TRUE)), na.rm = TRUE)   ) %>%   pivot_longer(everything(), names_to = "Variable_Type", values_to = "Outlier_Count") %>%   separate(Variable_Type, into = c("Variable", "Outlier_Type"), sep = "_", extra = "merge")  kable(extreme_values,       caption = "Extreme Value Counts by Variable")

title: ClinicoPath Descriptives 04: Data Quality Assessment for Clinical Research
code: # Create comprehensive quality summary quality_metrics <- data.frame(   Metric = c(     "Total Observations",     "Total Variables",      "Complete Cases",     "Variables with No Missing Data",     "Variables with <5% Missing",     "Variables with >20% Missing",     "Mean Completeness Rate"   ),   Value = c(     nrow(histopathology),     ncol(histopathology),     sum(complete.cases(histopathology)),     sum(missing_summary$Missing_Count == 0),     sum(missing_summary$Missing_Percentage <= 5),     sum(missing_summary$Missing_Percentage > 20),     paste0(round(mean(100 - missing_summary$Missing_Percentage), 1), "%")   ) )  kable(quality_metrics,       caption = "Data Quality Dashboard")

title: ClinicoPath Descriptives 04: Data Quality Assessment for Clinical Research
code: # Generate quality recommendations high_missing <- missing_summary %>%   filter(Missing_Percentage > 20) %>%   pull(Variable)  moderate_missing <- missing_summary %>%   filter(Missing_Percentage > 5 & Missing_Percentage <= 20) %>%   pull(Variable)  recommendations <- data.frame(   Priority = c("High", "Medium", "Low"),   Action = c(     ifelse(length(high_missing) > 0,             paste("Investigate high missing data in:", paste(high_missing, collapse = ", ")),            "No high-priority missing data issues"),     ifelse(length(moderate_missing) > 0,            paste("Consider imputation for:", paste(moderate_missing, collapse = ", ")),            "No moderate missing data issues"),      "Continue routine quality monitoring"   ) )  kable(recommendations,       caption = "Data Quality Recommendations")

title: ClinicoPath Descriptives 04: Data Quality Assessment for Clinical Research
code: # Analyze missing data patterns if(any(missing_summary$Missing_Count > 0)) {   # Create missing data profile   missing_profile <- histopathology %>%     summarise_all(~ifelse(is.na(.), "Missing", "Present")) %>%     pivot_longer(everything(), names_to = "Variable", values_to = "Status") %>%     count(Variable, Status) %>%     pivot_wider(names_from = Status, values_from = n, values_fill = 0) %>%     mutate(       Total = Missing + Present,       Missing_Rate = round(Missing / Total * 100, 1)     ) %>%     filter(Missing > 0) %>%     arrange(desc(Missing_Rate))      kable(missing_profile,         caption = "Missing Data Profile") }

title: ClinicoPath Descriptives 04: Data Quality Assessment for Clinical Research
code: # Summary of Benford's law results benford_summary <- data.frame(   Variable = c("MeasurementA", "MeasurementB", "OverallTime"),   Expected_Pattern = "Natural logarithmic distribution",   Assessment = c(     "Evaluate first digit distribution",     "Evaluate first digit distribution",      "Evaluate first digit distribution"   ),   Recommendation = "Review any significant deviations from expected pattern" )  kable(benford_summary,       caption = "Benford's Law Assessment Summary")

title: Comprehensive Guide to Alluvial Diagrams in ClinicoPath
text: Alluvial diagrams powerful visualization tools displaying categorical data flows relationships multiple categorical variables. ClinicoPath package provides comprehensive alluvial diagram functionality alluvial() function, offers extensive customization options clinical pathological research. vignette demonstrates available features parameters alluvial function using real clinical datasets.

title: Comprehensive Guide to Alluvial Diagrams in ClinicoPath
code: library(ClinicoPathDescriptives)  # Load the histopathology dataset data("histopathology")  # Preview the data structure str(histopathology[, c("Sex", "Race", "Group", "Grade_Level", "LVI", "PNI", "PreinvasiveComponent")])

title: Comprehensive Guide to Alluvial Diagrams in ClinicoPath
text: basic alluvial diagram shows flow three categorical variables:
code: # Basic alluvial diagram alluvial(     data = histopathology,     vars = c("Sex", "Grade_Level", "LVI") )

title: Comprehensive Guide to Alluvial Diagrams in ClinicoPath

code: # Four-variable alluvial diagram alluvial(     data = histopathology,     vars = c("Sex", "Race", "Group", "Grade_Level") )

title: Comprehensive Guide to Alluvial Diagrams in ClinicoPath

title: Comprehensive Guide to Alluvial Diagrams in ClinicoPath
code: # Create treatment response data for alluvial plot set.seed(123) treatment_data <- data.frame(   PreTreatment = sample(c("None", "Chemotherapy", "Radiation"), 100, replace = TRUE),   Treatment = sample(c("Surgery", "Chemotherapy", "Immunotherapy", "Combination"), 100, replace = TRUE),   Response = sample(c("Complete", "Partial", "Stable", "Progressive"), 100, replace = TRUE) )  # Use ggalluvial directly since jamovi functions don't work well in R Markdown library(ggalluvial) library(ggplot2)  ggplot(treatment_data, aes(axis1 = PreTreatment, axis2 = Treatment, axis3 = Response)) +   geom_alluvium(aes(fill = PreTreatment), width = 1/12) +   geom_stratum(width = 1/12, fill = "black", color = "grey") +   geom_label(stat = "stratum", aes(label = after_stat(stratum))) +   scale_x_discrete(limits = c("PreTreatment", "Treatment", "Response"), expand = c(.05, .05)) +   scale_fill_brewer(type = "qual", palette = "Set1") +   ggtitle("Treatment Response Pathways") +   theme_minimal()

title: Comprehensive Guide to Alluvial Diagrams in ClinicoPath
code: # Using colon cancer dataset data("colon")  # Analyze factors leading to outcomes alluvial(     data = colon,     vars = c("sex", "differ", "extent", "node4"),     fill = "last_variable",     excl = TRUE,     usetitle = TRUE,     mytitle = "Colon Cancer Prognostic Factors Flow" )

library(ClinicoPathDescriptives) library(dplyr) library(knitr)  # Load clinical research datasets data("histopathology") data("treatmentResponse")  # Display overview of available datasets cat("📊 Clinical Research Datasets Available:

title: Data Quality Assessment - Enhanced Visual Analysis with visdat Integration
text: enhanced data quality assessment workflow follows systematic steps: Variable Selection: Choose variables quality assessment Analysis Configuration: Select missing data, duplicates, visual analysis options Visual Analysis Type: Choose specific visdat analysis type Threshold Setting: Configure missing data highlight thresholds Export Options: Enable plot export publications Execution: Run comprehensive quality assessment Interpretation: Review results recommendations

title: Data Quality Assessment - Enhanced Visual Analysis with visdat Integration
text: Starting simple quality assessment core clinical variables. Expected Results: - Missing data analysis Age, Sex, Grade variables - Duplicate value detection within variable - Data completeness summary - Recommendations based quality findings
code: # Basic data quality assessment basic_quality <- dataquality(   data = histopathology,   vars = c("Age", "Sex", "Grade"),   check_duplicates = TRUE,   check_missing = TRUE,   complete_cases_only = FALSE,   visual_analysis = FALSE,  # Start without visual analysis   visdat_type = "vis_dat",   missing_threshold_visual = 10,   export_plots = FALSE )  # View basic quality results print("📋 Basic Data Quality Assessment:") print("================================") basic_quality$text

code: # Simulate ongoing clinical trial data trial_data <- data.frame(   patient_id = paste0("CT", sprintf("%03d", 1:75)),   enrollment_date = seq(as.Date("2024-01-01"), as.Date("2024-03-15"), length.out = 75),   primary_endpoint = c(     rnorm(60, 2.5, 1.2),  # Most patients     rep(NA, 10),          # Recent enrollments, not yet assessed     c(8.5, -2.1, 15.3, 0.1, 9.8)  # Some outliers   ),   safety_score = sample(0:4, 75, replace = TRUE, prob = c(0.4, 0.3, 0.2, 0.08, 0.02)),   treatment_group = factor(sample(c("Treatment", "Control"), 75, replace = TRUE)) )  # Monitor trial data quality trial_quality <- dataquality(   data = trial_data,   vars = c("primary_endpoint", "safety_score", "treatment_group"),   check_duplicates = FALSE,  # Not applicable for trial data   check_missing = TRUE,   complete_cases_only = TRUE,   visual_analysis = TRUE,   visdat_type = "vis_miss",  # Focus on missing patterns   missing_threshold_visual = 10,   export_plots = FALSE )  print("🏥 Clinical Trial Data Quality Monitoring:") trial_quality$text trial_quality$plot  # Check if quality meets regulatory standards missing_pct <- 100 * sum(is.na(trial_data$primary_endpoint)) / nrow(trial_data) if (missing_pct > 10) {   cat("⚠️  WARNING: Missing data exceeds 10% - investigate data collection procedures\n") } else {   cat("✅ PASS: Missing data within acceptable limits\n") }

code:
# Function for standardized pre-analysis quality assessment perform_preanalysis_quality_check <- function(data, primary_vars, secondary_vars = NULL) {      cat("📋 PRE-ANALYSIS QUALITY ASSESSMENT
")   cat("=================================
")      # Primary variables quality assessment   primary_quality <- dataquality(     data = data,     vars = primary_vars,     check_duplicates = TRUE,     check_missing = TRUE,     complete_cases_only = TRUE,     visual_analysis = TRUE,     visdat_type = "all_visual",     missing_threshold_visual = 5,  # Strict for primary variables     export_plots = TRUE   )      cat("PRIMARY VARIABLES ASSESSMENT:
")   cat("----------------------------
")   primary_quality$text      # Secondary variables if provided   if (!is.null(secondary_vars)) {     secondary_quality <- dataquality(       data = data,       vars = secondary_vars,       check_duplicates = TRUE,       check_missing = TRUE,       complete_cases_only = FALSE,       visual_analysis = TRUE,       visdat_type = "vis_miss",       missing_threshold_visual = 15,  # More lenient for secondary       export_plots = FALSE     )          cat("
SECONDARY VARIABLES ASSESSMENT:
")     cat("------------------------------
")     secondary_quality$text   }      return(list(primary = primary_quality, secondary = secondary_quality)) }  # Example usage primary_vars <- c("Age", "Sex", "Grade", "TStage") secondary_vars <- c("LVI", "PNI", "MeasurementA", "MeasurementB")  quality_results <- perform_preanalysis_quality_check(   data = histopathology,   primary_vars = primary_vars,   secondary_vars = secondary_vars )

text: dataquality function provides implicit quality grading based analysis results: Grade : Excellent Quality - Missing data: 0-5% - Minimal duplicates - Appropriate data types - systematic patterns Grade B: Good Quality - Missing data: 5-15% - duplicate patterns - Minor type issues - Limited systematic concerns Grade C: Concerning Quality - Missing data: 15-30% - Notable duplicate issues - Type validation problems - Systematic patterns detected Grade D: Poor Quality - Missing data: >30% - Significant quality issues - Multiple systematic problems - Requires intervention

")   cat("Generated on:", Sys.Date(), "
")   cat("Dataset:", deparse(substitute(data)), "
")   cat("Variables analyzed:", length(variables), "
")   cat("Observations:", nrow(data), "

")      # Comprehensive quality assessment   quality_result <- dataquality(     data = data,     vars = variables,     check_duplicates = TRUE,     check_missing = TRUE,     complete_cases_only = TRUE,     visual_analysis = TRUE,     visdat_type = "all_visual",     missing_threshold_visual = 10,     export_plots = TRUE   )      cat("QUALITY ASSESSMENT RESULTS:
")   cat("-------------------------
")   quality_result$text      cat("
VISUAL ANALYSIS:
")   cat("---------------
")   quality_result$plot      return(quality_result) }  # Generate report for histopathology data quality_report <- generate_quality_report(   data = histopathology,   variables = c("Age", "Sex", "Grade", "TStage", "LVI", "PNI"),   report_title = "Histopathology Data Quality Report" )

# Basic correlation analysis correlation_ki67 <- cor(digital_pathology_validation$Ki67_Manual,                         digital_pathology_validation$Ki67_AI_Assisted)  cat("Ki-67 Manual vs AI Correlation:", round(correlation_ki67, 3), "
")  # Correlation by tumor type correlation_by_tumor <- digital_pathology_validation %>%   group_by(Tumor_Type) %>%   summarise(     correlation = round(cor(Ki67_Manual, Ki67_AI_Assisted), 3),     n = n(),     .groups = 'drop'   ) %>%   arrange(desc(correlation))  print("Correlation by Tumor Type (Top 10):") print(head(correlation_by_tumor, 10))  # Statistical significance testing cor_test <- cor.test(digital_pathology_validation$Ki67_Manual,                      digital_pathology_validation$Ki67_AI_Assisted)  cat("Correlation test p-value:", formatC(cor_test$p.value, format = "e", digits = 2), "
") cat("95% CI:", round(cor_test$conf.int[1], 3), "to", round(cor_test$conf.int[2], 3), "
")
